awd_titl_txt: Architecture and Attributes of Gas Vesicles
awd_abstract_narration:
ID: MPS/DMR/BMAT(7623) 1305713  	              PI:  Herzfeld, Judith	                  ORG: Brandeis University

Title:  Architecture and Attributes of Gas Vesicles

Technical:  The hollow, spindle-shaped floatation vesicles of aquatic micro-organisms have remarkable physical properties.  The 2.0 nm thick proteinaceous wall is impermeable to water but permeable to gas molecules considerably larger than water.  Vesicles measuring 75 nm in width and up to 1000 nm in length can withstand as much as 10 atmospheres of hydrostatic pressure.  The wall, assembled almost exclusively from repeating units of the highly hydrophobic 7 kDa gas vesicle protein A (gvpA), cannot be solubilized with detergents.  While it is difficult to imagine how nature achieves these mechanical, interfacial, and permeability properties, it is also clear, from the strong homology among gvpA's across all organisms, that nature has not found many ways of doing it.  Furthermore, the absence of homology with other proteins indicates that the gas vesicle construct is a very special one.  The general goal of the project is to understand the structural features of gas vesicles that are responsible for their properties.  Two systems will be studied, one adapted to fresh water and the other adapted to highly saline conditions.  The work will employ solid state NMR experiments and atomistic modeling.  Solid state NMR has the advantage of being able to measure internuclear distances in systems not amenable to either solubilization or crystallization.  This information will allow modeling of the complete structure and the interfacial properties of the gas vesicle shell, taking fully into account the periodicity and the asymmetric environment of the vesicle wall.  Comparisons between vesicles adapted to fresh water and vesicles adapted to highly saline conditions will help in assigning functional significance to different structural features. 

Non-Technical:  From a practical point of view, the gas vesicles of aquatic micro-organisms are finding direct use in a number of contexts.  In particular, they have been used to confer buoyancy in cells that normally do not float, to improve oxygen perfusion in anchorage-dependent cell cultures, and as vaccination vehicles.  It is expected that detailed knowledge of gas vesicle structure will allow these direct applications to be fine-tuned with respect to engineering interactions with wild type vesicles or choosing mutant vesicles.  In addition, understanding how nature has designed gas vesicles may inspire the design of new materials that make use of the same underlying principles.  Of particular interest are the origins of the resistance of the vesicle walls to detergents and proteases, their mechanical strength, their high permeability to gases, and the anticipated extreme dewetting behavior of their inner surface.  Education and outreach activities associated with this project will include direct involvement of undergraduates from the Brandeis University Science Posse program during the summer, hands-on activities for students in field trips to campus from underserved high schools in the greater Boston area, and instruction with hands-on activities in the Kroka Expeditions program that serves teens primarily from New Hampshire and Vermont.

por.por_cntn:
Gas vesicles are the floatation organelles of aquatic micro-organisms. By assembling many copies of a protein GvpA into cylindrical shells enclosing a gas filled cavity, the organisms are able to adjust their depth in the water column to make the best use of light and nutrients. The vesicles shells are thin yet resilient, and are permeable to molecules larger than water yet prevent water from condensing inside. Our work seeks to understand these exceptional material properties using solid state NMR spectroscopy and theoretical modeling.

NMR:

Since gas vesicles are particularly strong and abundant in deep water micro-organisms like A.flos-aquae these have received the most attention from researchers. In these vesicles we have been able to obtain information about the protein fold that contributes to the strength of the shell and the hydrophobicity of its interior surface. Among other things, we determined that these organisms add extra strength to their vesicles by building with asymmetric GvpA dimers in which one of the GvpA molecules is folded in a second, higher energy form. While this manner of investing in vesicle strength is interesting in itself, the dimorphism made it more difficult to extract information about the way in which the GvpA dimers come together to form the complete vesicle shell. In contrast, we found that H.salinarum, an organism that grows in salt flats, does not use dimorphism, presumably because it does not need such strong vesicles in its shallow habitat. On the other hand, the larger size of this organism’s GvpA, combined with its stretches of contiguous valine residues, prevented an adequate assignment of NMR signals. For this reason, we looked to H.mediterranei, which has both a smaller GvpA and a shallow habitat. Here we were able to verify the expected absence of dimorphism. However, these vesicles proved too unstable for efficient preparation of the various samples required for a thorough NMR study.

Modeling:

Gas vesicles are small enough that the amount of water vapor they can contain is too small for homogeneous nucleation of condensation to occur in the lifetime of the organism. The question therefore is how heterogeneous nucleation is prevented. To understand the mechanism, we need a good model for the interaction of water with the interior surface of the vesicle. Unfortunately, the interactions of water are particularly difficult to model. Quantum mechanical approaches have required problematic approximations in order to model the numerous electrons in the relevant numbers of molecules. Meanwhile, molecular mechanics approaches make even greater approximations in the process of taking only implicit account of electrons. Our approach is to treat the electrons explicitly, but in a semi-classical manner. We have found that this  provides the best agreement with experiment for the surface propensities of the water self-ions, hydroxide and hydronium (as well as for the rates and pathways for recombination of these ions). At the same time, it provides the best description of the polarizability of water and its high frequency conductivity, both of which are important for its interaction with any surface.
